eureka_ml_insights.data_utils package

Submodules

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.aime_utils module

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.aime_utils.AIMEExtractAnswer(model_output_column, model_answer_column)

Bases: DFTransformBase

A data transformation class that extracts an AIME answer from the model’s output.

model_output_column

The name of the column in the DataFrame containing the model output.

Type:

str

model_answer_column

The name of the column in the DataFrame where the extracted answer will be stored.

Type:

str

model_answer_column: str
model_output_column: str
static parse_output_answer(response)

Parses the input string to extract the answer of a given AIME question.

Parameters:

response (str) – Input string containing the answer in the form of “Final Answer: X”.

Returns:

A numeric value representing the model’s answer.

Return type:

float

transform(df)

Transforms the given DataFrame by extracting the AIME answer from the model’s output column.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame to be transformed.

Returns:

The transformed DataFrame with the extracted answers in the specified column.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.ba_calendar_utils module

This module provides the BA_Calendar_ExtractAnswer class, which transforms a DataFrame to extract answers from a model output column for BA Calendar problems.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.ba_calendar_utils.BA_Calendar_ExtractAnswer(model_output_column, model_answer_column)

Bases: DFTransformBase

Extracts answers from a model output column in a DataFrame.

This class extends DFTransformBase, providing a transformation method to parse and extract BA Calendar problem answers from a specified output column.

model_output_column

The name of the column containing the model output.

Type:

str

model_answer_column

The name of the column that will store the parsed answers.

Type:

str

model_answer_column: str
model_output_column: str
static parse_output_answer(response)

Parses the input string to extract an answer for BA Calendar problems.

Parameters:

response (str) – The input string containing the answer in the form of “Final Answer: X”.

Returns:

A string representing the extracted answer. If no valid answer is found, returns an empty string or “No common time slot available” if applicable.

Return type:

str

transform(df)

Transforms the given DataFrame by parsing the model output column to extract answers.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing the model output column.

Returns:

The transformed DataFrame with a new column containing the parsed answers.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.data module

Module containing data loader classes, reader/writer classes, and supporting utilities for local or remote data ingestion and consumption.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.data.AzureBlobReader

Bases: object

Provides functionality to read data from an Azure Storage blob via a full blob URL.

Reads content from an Azure Storage blob.

Parameters:

blob_url (str) – The full URL of the Azure blob.

Returns:

The content of the blob as a string.

Return type:

str

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.data.AzureDataAuthenticator

Bases: object

Handles Azure authentication parameters for blob storage.

get_query_string(query_string=None, secret_key_params=None)

Obtains an Azure query string for authentication.

One of the two arguments (query_string or secret_key_params) must be provided.

Parameters:

  • query_string (str, optional) – The query string to authenticate with Azure Blob Storage. Defaults to None.

  • secret_key_params (dict, optional) – Parameters for retrieving the query string from secrets. Defaults to None.

Raises:

ValueError – If neither query_string nor secret_key_params are provided.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.dna_utils module

This module provides a transform class to parse DNA labels from model outputs, and associated helper functions to parse the output labels.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.dna_utils.DNAParseLabel(model_output_column, model_action_label_column, model_harmless_label_column, use_updated_metric)

Bases: DFTransformBase

Transformer to parse DNA label columns from model output.

model_output_column

The column name containing the model output.

Type:

str

model_action_label_column

The column name to store the parsed action label.

Type:

str

model_harmless_label_column

The column name to store the parsed harmless label.

Type:

str

use_updated_metric

A flag indicating whether to use the updated parsing logic.

Type:

bool

model_action_label_column: str
model_harmless_label_column: str
model_output_column: str
transform(df)

Transforms a DataFrame by parsing model output columns into action labels.

Parameters:

df (pd.DataFrame) – The input DataFrame containing model output columns.

Returns:

A DataFrame with updated action label and harmless label columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

use_updated_metric: bool
eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.dna_utils.parse_output_label(s)

Parses the output string to extract the model-predicted label.

Parameters:

s (str) – The model output string containing labels in <answer>index</answer> format.

Returns:

The extracted label index. Returns -1 if parsing fails.

Return type:

int

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.dna_utils.parse_output_label_updated(s)

Parses the output string to extract the model-predicted label using updated logic.

Addresses edge cases by treating integers <0 or >6 as invalid (-1).

Parameters:

s (str) – The model output string containing labels in <answer>index</answer> format.

Returns:

The extracted label index. Returns -1 for invalid or failed parsing.

Return type:

int

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.encoders module

This module provides classes and functions for JSON encoding of numpy data types.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.encoders.NumpyEncoder(*, skipkeys=False, ensure_ascii=True, check_circular=True, allow_nan=True, sort_keys=False, indent=None, separators=None, default=None)

Bases: JSONEncoder

Encodes numpy data types into JSON-compatible formats.

Extends the standard json.JSONEncoder to handle numeric, array, and bytes objects from numpy.

default(obj)

Returns a JSON-serializable version of the given object.

If the object is a numpy integer or float, it is converted to the appropriate Python type (int or float). If the object is a numpy array, it is converted to a list. If the object is a bytes object, it is Base64-encoded. Otherwise, the default json.JSONEncoder method is called.

Parameters:

obj (Any) – The object to serialize.

Returns:

A JSON-serializable representation of the given object.

Return type:

Any

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.flenqa_utils.normalize_answer(s)

Lowers the text, removes punctuation, articles, and extra white spaces.

This code is adapted from: https://github.com/alonj/Same-Task-More-Tokens

Parameters:

s (str) – The string to normalize.

Returns:

The normalized string.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.flenqa_utils.response_analysis(response, dataset, facts, statement, is_valid, chain_of_thought=False)

Analyzes the model response by calculating chain of thought coverage, response category, and early response.

This code is taken and adapted from: https://github.com/alonj/Same-Task-More-Tokens

Parameters:

  • response (str) – The model output to analyze.

  • dataset (str) – The dataset name which is a column in the original flenQA dataset.

  • facts (list) – The facts column from the original flenQA dataset.

  • statement (list) – The statement column from the original flenQA dataset.

  • is_valid (bool) – Indicates if the response is valid.

  • chain_of_thought (bool) – Indicates if a chain of thought prompt was used. Defaults to False.

Returns:

A pandas Series containing analysis results.

Return type:

pd.Series

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.flenqa_utils.response_category(ans)

Categorizes the answer as “true,” “false,” or “none.”

This code is adapted from: https://github.com/alonj/Same-Task-More-Tokens

Parameters:

ans (str) – The string to categorize.

Returns:

The category of the answer.

static parse_output_answer(response)

Extracts a numeric answer from a given GSM8K response string.

This function looks for the answer text after “####”, strips unwanted characters, and attempts to convert it to a float. If the conversion fails, it returns None.

Parameters:

response (str) – The raw string response containing the answer.

Returns:

The numeric value of the answer, or None if parsing fails.

float

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.kitab_utils module

Module for parsing and transforming book data from the Kitab dataset.

This module provides classes and functions to parse model outputs, extract book information, and prepare context data. It includes utilities to handle specific modifications and standard output marker additions for more consistent data parsing. Additionally, it provides a method to retrieve GPT-4 preprocessed names from a specified dataset.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.kitab_utils.add_output_marker(s)

Adds an ‘Output:n’ marker to the given string if needed.

If the string does not contain ‘Output:n’, and it starts with ‘1.’, this function will prepend ‘Output:n’ to the string.

Parameters:

s (str) – The input string.

Returns:

The possibly modified string with an output marker.

Return type:

str

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.kitab_utils.get_gpt4_preprocessed_names(original_path, download_path)

Downloads book titles preprocessed by GPT-4 that contain human names.

This function retrieves a CSV file from the provided URL, reads the data, and collects book titles from a JSON-like column containing a dictionary with a list of ‘titles’.

Parameters:

  • original_path (str) – The URL or path to download the CSV from.

  • download_path (str) – The local path to store the downloaded CSV.

Returns:

A list of book titles extracted from the downloaded CSV.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.kitab_utils.parse_output_reason(s)

Parses the input string to extract titles and reasons from the ‘Output:’ section.

The function looks for the substring ‘Output:n’, and if found, processes the subsequent text to extract pairs of reason and title. The extracted data is returned as a dictionary with keys ‘titles’ and ‘reasons’.

Parameters:

s (str) – The input string containing information with an ‘Output:’ section.

Returns:

A dictionary with keys ‘titles’ and ‘reasons’, each containing a list

of extracted values. Example: {‘titles’: [‘Title 1’, ‘Title 2’], ‘reasons’: [‘Reason 1’, ‘Reason 2’]}

Return type:

dict

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.kitab_utils.prepare_all_books_context(s)

Parses the array of all books and presents it in a specific text format.

This function reads the string representation of a list of books, and returns a string in which each book is followed by four spaces and a newline.

Parameters:

s (str) – The string representing a list of books.

Returns:

A formatted string of book titles, each on its own line.

Return type:

str

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.delete_extra_zero(n)

Removes unnecessary trailing zeros from a numeric string.

Tries to convert the input to a float. If successful, trailing zeros (including trailing decimal points) are removed. Otherwise, the original string is returned.

Parameters:

n (str) – The numeric string to process.

Returns:

A string with trailing zeros removed or the original string if

conversion fails.

Return type:

str

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.eval_tuple(s)

Evaluates mathematical expressions within tuples or lists represented as strings.

Splits the string by commas to evaluate each element using latex2sympy, rounding the result to 2 decimal places when applicable.

Parameters:

s (str) – The string representation of a tuple or list, e.g., “(2*3, 5+2)” or “[2*3, 5+2]”.

Returns:

A string representation of the tuple or list with evaluated expressions. Returns the original string if it doesn’t match the expected format or if an error occurs.

Return type:

str

Example

>>> eval_tuple("(2*3, 5+2)")
'(6,7)'
eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.evaluate(model_output, answer, options)

Evaluates the model output against a ground truth answer or set of options.

If the model output is empty, returns False. Otherwise, attempts to parse the final answer and compares it to the ground truth. If multiple choice options exist, uses the letter in ‘answer’ to select the correct option.

Parameters:

  • model_output (str) – The raw text output from the model.

  • answer (str) – The ground truth answer (can be a letter if options are provided).

  • options (list) – A list of potential multiple choice answers.

Returns:

True if the model output is equivalent to the ground truth answer,

otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.extract_answer(completion)

Extracts a numeric answer from a string using the pattern ‘#### XY’.

Uses a regex to match the pattern. If a match is found, commas are removed. If no match is found, an AssertionError is raised.

Parameters:

completion (str) – The string from which to extract the answer.

Returns:

The matched numeric substring without commas.

Return type:

str

Raises:

AssertionError – If no suitable match is found.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.extract_nums(s)

Extracts numeric values from a string.

Removes commas and uses a regex to find numeric substrings. Attempts to evaluate them as floats or integers for return.

Parameters:

s (str) – The string from which to extract numbers.

Returns:

A list of numerical values (floats) extracted from the string.

Return type:

list

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.find_formula(step)

Finds a formula enclosed within ‘<<’ and ‘>>’ in a string.

Asserts that the string contains exactly one pair of ‘<<’ and ‘>>’, then extracts the substring between them.

Parameters:

step (str) – The string containing the formula.

Returns:

The substring between the ‘<<’ and ‘>>’.

Return type:

str

Raises:

AssertionError – If the string doesn’t contain exactly one matching pair of ‘<<’ and ‘>>’.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.find_math_answer(s)

Extracts and cleans the final mathematical answer from a LaTeX string.

Attempts to locate the substring after certain patterns (e.g., ‘boxed{}’), then strips and fixes LaTeX formatting.

Parameters:

s (str) – The LaTeX string from which to extract the math answer.

Returns:

The cleaned math answer.

Return type:

str

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.mathvision_utils.in_area(id, area)

Checks if a given ID falls within a specified area.

The function returns True if the area is ‘all’ or if the ID contains the specified area string or matches the pattern for a test CSV of that area.

Parameters:

  • id (str) – The ID to check.

  • area (str) – The area of interest or ‘all’.

Returns:

True if the ID matches the specified area or if the area is ‘all’,

otherwise False.

Return type:

bool

Examples

>>> in_area("abstract_algebra_test.csv_1", "algebra")
True
>>> in_area("test/precalculus/244.json", "precalculus")
True
>>> in_area("abstract_algebra_test.csv_1", "precalculus")
False

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_sat_utils.convert_to_binary_string(solution)

Converts a comma-separated list of “True”/”False” flags to a comma-separated list of “1”/”0”.

Any token other than exactly “True” or “False” is converted to “-1”.

Example

>>> convert_to_binary_string("True, False, True, True")
'1,0,1,1'
Parameters:

solution (str) – A comma-separated string containing “True” or “False” values.

Returns:

A comma-separated string of “1” and “0”, or “-1” if invalid input is encountered.

Return type:

str

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_sat_utils.extract_final_answer(model_output)

model_output (str) – The raw output from the model, which may contain <final_answer> blocks.

Returns:

The content within the final <final_answer>…</final_answer> block, or None if no block is found.

Return type:

Optional[str]

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_tsp_utils module

This module provides functionality for extracting TSP paths from model output.

It includes: 1) A data transform class (NPHARDTSPExtractAnswer) that organizes extraction in a DataFrame. 2) Utility functions (extract_final_answer, extract_path, parse_path_from_model_output) to parse TSP paths from raw strings.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_tsp_utils.NPHARDTSPExtractAnswer(model_output_column, model_answer_column)

Bases: DFTransformBase

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_tsp_utils.extract_final_answer(model_output)

Extracts the final answer from the model output.

Finds all non-overlapping occurrences between <final_answer> and </final_answer> and returns the last occurrence if any are found, otherwise returns None.

Parameters:

model_output (str) – The raw output string from the model.

Returns:

The last occurrence of the final answer if found, otherwise None.

Return type:

str or None

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_tsp_utils.extract_path(final_answer)

Extracts the path string from the final answer.

This function tries to parse the final answer as JSON or uses a regex fallback to extract the “Path” value.

Parameters:

final_answer (str) – The final answer string extracted from model output.

Returns:

The path string if extracted, otherwise None.

Return type:

str or None

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.nphard_tsp_utils.parse_path_from_model_output(model_output_string)

Parses the model output to extract a TSP path.

This function extracts the final answer, then attempts to retrieve the path and parse it into a list of integers. If no valid path is found, a default path “0,0,0,0” is returned.

Parameters:

model_output_string (str) – The raw output string from the model.

Returns:

A comma-separated string of integers indicating the TSP path.

Return type:

str

The code is from: https://github.com/alvinmingwisc/spatial_reason_vlm/tree/main/eval, and included with minimal modifications.

Extracts the answer from the text based on known model output patterns.

The code is from: https://github.com/alvinmingwisc/spatial_reason_vlm/tree/main/eval, and included with minimal modifications.

Parameters:

  • model_output_raw (str) – The text containing the model’s answer.

  • options (str) – The list of options.

  • is_valid (bool) – Whether the input is valid.

  • match_first (bool, optional) – If True, the first match is used for answer extraction when multiple matches are found. Defaults to False.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.toxigen_utils module

This module provides classes and functions to parse and label toxicity scores from model outputs. It includes data transformations for both discriminative and generative evaluation settings.

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.toxigen_utils.label_category_map(s)

Derive ground-truth and category labels from the dataset split string.

Parameters:

s (str) – Refers to various splits in the dataset (e.g., ‘neutral_black_1k’).

Returns:

A tuple (str, str). The first element is the ground-truth label (“toxic” if the split starts with ‘hate’, otherwise “neutral”). The second element is the category label derived from the split string.

Return type:

tuple

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.toxigen_utils.parse_output(s, delimiters, generative=False)

Parse the input string to extract toxicity scores.

Parameters:

  • s (str) – Input string containing the model’s output.

  • delimiters (list) – List of delimiters used to search for scores in the string.

  • generative (bool) – If True, returns the raw score instead of the “neutral” or “toxic” label.

Returns:

A tuple (str, bool). The first element is either the extracted score/label or a placeholder string indicating no score was found, and the second element is a boolean indicating whether a valid score was found.

Return type:

tuple

eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.transform module

A set of classes and transformations for DataFrame modifications.

This module includes a base class (DFTransformBase), along with a variety of transformations for renaming columns, running Python code, sampling data, repeating rows, adding columns, and more.

class eureka_ml_insights.data_utils.transform.MajorityVoteTransform(model_output_col='model_output', model_label_column=None, id_col='data_point_id', majority_vote_col='majority_vote', majority_label_col='majority_label')

static majority_vote(group, model_output_col, model_label_col, majority_vote_col, majority_label_col, random_state=0)

Calculates the majority vote for each group and optionally its corresponding label.

Parameters:

  • group (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame group containing model outputs.

  • model_output_col (str) – The model output column name.

  • model_label_col (str) – The model label column name corresponding to outputs.

  • majority_vote_col (str) – The column name for storing the majority vote result.

  • majority_label_col (str) – The column name for storing the label of the majority vote output.

  • random_state (int, optional) – The random seed for tie-breaking among the mode values. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

The group DataFrame with columns for the majority vote and optional label.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame

majority_vote_col: str = 'majority_vote'
model_label_column: str = None
model_output_col: str = 'model_output'
transform(df, random_state=0)

Calculates the majority vote of model outputs for each group identified by ‘id_col’.

If the model output is NaN, it will be dropped before calculating the majority vote.

Parameters:

  • df (pd.DataFrame) – The DataFrame containing model outputs and IDs.

  • random_state (int, optional) – The random seed for tie-breaking among the mode values. Defaults to 0.

Returns:

The transformed DataFrame, including majority vote columns.

Return type:

pd.DataFrame
